skill.description: Verify performance implications were considered and no obvious anti-patterns exist. Issues result in WARNINGS.

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation and guidelines. No executable code, network access, filesystem access, or external commands detected.

content.user_title: Catch performance anti-patterns in code reviews
content.value_statement: Performance issues are hard to spot during initial development but cause problems at scale. This gate provides clear checklists and Socratic questions to identify N+1 queries, inefficient loops, and rendering problems before they become issues.
actual_capabilities: Review code for N+1 query patterns in database operations
Check for missing pagination on list endpoints
Identify inefficient loops and nested iterations
Detect expensive computations in render cycles
Verify memoization and callback usage in frontend code
Check for proper cleanup of intervals and subscriptions
limitations: Does not execute code or measure actual performance
Does not integrate with profiling tools
Focuses on obvious patterns, not micro-optimizations

use_cases.title: Systematic performance review
use_cases.description: Apply consistent performance checks during code reviews using built-in checklists for database, frontend, and API code.

use_cases.title: Database query analysis
use_cases.description: Catch N+1 queries, verify pagination implementation, and ensure bulk operations are used where appropriate.

use_cases.title: Render optimization check
use_cases.description: Identify unnecessary re-renders, verify memoization usage, and check for expensive calculations in component bodies.

prompt_templates.title: Basic performance check
prompt_templates.scenario: Review a function for performance issues
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this code for performance issues. Check for: N+1 queries, missing pagination, inefficient loops, expensive render operations, and missing cleanup. Report findings with specific locations.

prompt_templates.title: Database query audit
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze all database queries in this code. Identify any queries inside loops, check if pagination is implemented, and verify indexes are used on queried columns. List each issue with line numbers.

prompt_templates.title: Frontend render analysis
prompt_templates.scenario: Check React components for render issues
prompt_templates.prompt: Review these React components for performance issues. Look for: inline functions passed as props, expensive calculations without useMemo, missing useCallback on handlers, and array operations in render body.

prompt_templates.title: Scalability assessment
prompt_templates.prompt: Evaluate this code for scalability concerns. Consider: What happens with 10,000 items? Are there nested loops? Is data fetching efficient? Could memory grow unbounded? Return specific concerns with Big O analysis.

output_examples.input: Review this function for performance issues
output: - No expensive computations in render cycle

best_practices: Use bulk operations and joins instead of queries inside loops
Implement pagination for any endpoint returning list data
Memoize expensive computations and wrap event handlers with useCallback
Always cleanup intervals, subscriptions, and listeners in effect return functions
anti_patterns: Querying inside loops (N+1 problem) instead of batching
Fetching all records without pagination or limits
Creating new functions or objects inline in JSX causing re-renders
Performing expensive operations like sorting or filtering on every render without memoization

faq.question: What is the N+1 query problem?
faq.answer: N+1 occurs when code fetches a list of items, then makes a separate database query for each item. One query to get the list plus N queries for related data.

faq.question: Does this gate detect all performance issues?
faq.answer: No. This gate catches obvious anti-patterns. Complex algorithmic issues, memory leaks in depth, and actual performance measurements require profiling tools.

faq.question: Can I use this with my existing code review workflow?
faq.answer: Yes. This gate works standalone or integrates with any review process. Use the checklists as a guide during manual reviews.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this gate?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a prompt-based skill with no code execution. It only reviews code you provide and does not access files, network, or system resources.

faq.question: What if I disagree with a warning?
faq.answer: Warnings are advisory. If you have justification for the pattern (small dataset, prototype phase), you can acknowledge and proceed.

faq.question: How is this different from linters?
faq.answer: Linters catch syntax and style issues. This gate evaluates design patterns and scalability concerns that require human judgment to assess.
